channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Jet’s Disappearance Puzzles a World Under Constant Electronic Watch
item.description: The continuing uncertainty, with no evidence of what happened to the plane and the people on it, has tormented relatives of those on board and flummoxed aviation experts.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: An Australian search team flew over a boat looking for debris in the Indian Ocean on Saturday.

item.title: N.S.A. Breached Chinese Servers Seen as Security Threat
item.description: As the United States made a public case about the dangers of buying from Huawei, the Chinese telecommunications giant, classified documents show that the National Security Agency was creating its own back doors — directly into Huawei’s networks.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and NICOLE PERLROTH

item.title: Ukrainian Soldier Wounded as Russian Forces Attack a Crimean Base
item.description: One Ukraine soldier was wounded after armored vehicles rammed through the gates at Belbek and the forces fired shots in the air and threw grenades.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: In Beijing Talk, Michelle Obama Extols Free Speech
item.description: The first lady told an audience of mainly students that unfettered expression, particularly on the Internet and in the news media, form the basis for a strong, prosperous society.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: “Time and again, we have seen that countries are stronger and more prosperous when the voices and opinions of all their citizens can be heard.”

item.title: Chinese Satellite Spots Object in Search Area for Missing Jetliner
item.description: The object, which Chinese ships are being sent to investigate, is in the area of one of two possible routes investigators think the plane took.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: China's State Administration of Science, Technology and Industry, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The object spotted in the Indian Ocean on Saturday is said to be about 74 feet long and 43 feet wide.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: As Numbers Swell, Students Pledge to Continue Occupying Taiwan’s Legislature
item.description: Demonstrators angered by moves to push a trade bill with China through Taiwan’s Legislature have called for talks with the government.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: In Turkey, Twitter Roars After Effort to Block It
item.description: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s ban drew international outrage and was defied by thousands of Turks, including President Abdullah Gul, who protested — using Twitter.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Two Turkish women in a cafe in Istanbul hoped to connect to Twitter on Friday after the prime minister tried to shut it down.

item.title: World Briefing: North Korea: Rockets Fired in a Test Land in the Sea
item.description: North Korea test-fired 30 short-range rockets off its east coast on Saturday, the latest in a series of military actions condemned by South Korea.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: As Sanctions Start, Russia Feels a Sting
item.description: With the onset of sanctions, Russia’s stock indexes opened sharply lower and agencies threatened to cut the country’s creditworthiness, but President Vladimir V. Putin’s oligarchs stood by him.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian soldiers digging a trench at a Ukrainian military base in Crimea. Russia made its annexation of Crimea official Friday.

item.title: Russia’s Shifting of Border Force Stirs U.S. Worry
item.description: The national security adviser, Susan E. Rice, expressed skepticism that troop movements on the border of southern and eastern Ukraine were merely training exercises.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Susan E. Rice, the national security adviser, with her deputy, Benjamin J. Rhodes, at a White House briefing on Friday.

item.title: Nations Start to Collaborate in the Search
item.description: The expansion of the multinational operation off the western coast of Australia illustrates how the hunt for the Malaysia Airlines plane has helped dampen regional tensions.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: This handout from the Australian Maritime Safety Authority shows the satellite images of the two objects that officials say could possibly be related to Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

item.title: Illusion of Safety at Afghan Haven Is Shattered
item.description: A deadly attack by Taliban insurgents on a Kabul hotel favored by Westerners and the Afghan elite reinforced fears that the election to replace President Hamid Karzai will be accompanied by widening bloodshed.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Security officials outside the Serena Hotel in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Friday, a day after the fatal attack by Taliban insurgents.

item.title: Russian Defiance Is Seen as a Confidence Builder for Syria’s Government
item.description: The prospect of a deal brokered by Russian and American officials to end the Syrian war seems increasingly remote, as bonds deepen between Moscow and Damascus.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Supporters of President Bashar al-Assad rallied in Homs, Syria. Analysts said Russia's stance over the Ukraine crisis could strengthen Mr. Assad's hold on power.

item.title: In Paris Campaign, Left and Right Have One Thing in Common
item.description: Paris is on the eve of electing its first female mayor: Anne Hidalgo of the Socialist Party or Nathalie Kosciusko-Morizet of the conservative Union for a Popular Movement.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Nathalie Kosciusko-Morizet, 40, one of the few prominent women in France’s conservative Union for a Popular Movement party, comes from a well-heeled family with Polish ancestry.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Highly Enriched Danger
item.description: The case against using weapons-grade fuel in naval reactors.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ALAN J. KUPERMAN and FRANK N. VON HIPPEL

item.title: World Briefing: Mali: Fire Destroys Shops in the Capital’s Main Market
item.description: An overnight blaze at the main market in Mali’s capital, Bamako, destroyed about 2,000 shops, causing millions of dollars in damage.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Cuba: Pay Increases Announced for Medical Workers
item.description: Cuba is giving hundreds of thousands of medical workers raises, the state-run newspaper announced Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Brazil: Rio de Janeiro Asks for Help to Fight Crime
item.description: Brazil will send federal troops to Rio de Janeiro to help quell a surge in violent crime after attacks by drug traffickers on police posts.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Beware of Cold-Blooded Americans
item.description: Invasive U.S. turtles take all the good nesting spots and basking sites.
item.dc:creator: By VANESSA BARBARA

item.title: The Saturday Profile: One Foot in Each of Two Worlds, and a Pen at Home in Both
item.description: The writer Leila Aboulela, who was born in Egypt and raised in Sudan, and has long lived in Scotland, is sometimes criticized for taking a perspective outside of a purely Muslim, Arab or African viewpoint.
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH
item.media:credit: Isma'il Kushkush for The New York Times

item.title: The Lede: Malaysian Opposition Leader Calls Speculation About Pilot of Missing Jet ‘Absurd’
item.description: The s opposition leader, Anwar Ibrahim, dismissed speculation that the pilot, a supporter of his movement for democratic change, might have hijacked the plane for political reasons.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: The Lede: Pilot of Missing Jet Expressed Interest in Democracy and Atheism on Social Networks
item.description: Posts on the Facebook and YouTube accounts maintained by Capt. Zaharie Ahmad Shah support descriptions of him by friends as a man without extremist leanings in religion or politics.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: The Lede: Turks Evade Twitter Ban to Mock Twitter Ban, on Twitter
item.description: Turkey’s court-ordered ban on Twitter was widely subverted by many of the 12 million Turkish users of the social network, who found ways to gain access to the platform and posted defiant messages of protest.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Lawrence E. Walsh, Prosecutor in Iran-Contra Scandal, Dies at 102
item.description: As an independent counsel, Mr. Walsh exposed the lawbreaking in the administration of President Ronald Reagan that gave rise to the Iran-contra scandal.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL A. LEWIS
item.media:description: Lawrence E. Walsh, shown in 1989, spent more than six years and about $37 million investigating the illegal sale of arms to Iran by the Reagan administration.

item.title: Border Patrol Seeks to Add Digital Eyes to Its Ranks
item.description: The Border Patrol is focusing on concentrating Border Patrol agents, equipped with late-model surveillance tools, in areas of frequent illegal traffic, while using aerial drones to monitor remote, lightly trafficked spots.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA PRESTON
item.media:credit: Samantha Sais for The New York Times
item.media:description: A portable surveillance tower at the Border Security Expo in Phoenix, Ariz., in March.
